content:
MenuItemArray Class

In this Article

Provides a control array of MenuItem controls.

Syntax

Declaration

[System.ComponentModel.ProvideProperty("Index", typeof(System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem))]
[System.Obsolete("Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.* classes are obsolete and supported within 32 bit processes only. http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=160862")]
public class MenuItemArray : Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray, System.ComponentModel.IExtenderProvider

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • Object
  • MarshalByRefObject
  • Component
  • Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray
  • MenuItemArray

Remarks

The MenuItemArray class provides an equivalent for the run-time functionality of a Visual Basic 6.0 MenuItem array. It does not provide the design-time features of a Visual Basic 6.0 control array.

Note

Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Initializes a new instance of the MenuItemArray class.
MenuItemArray(IContainer)

Initializes a new instance of the MenuItemArray class, specifying its container.

Gets a specific element of a MenuItemArray by index. Read-only.

Gets a value that determines whether a control is a member of a MenuItemArray.

Overrides crosoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray.GetControlInstanceType*.

Gets the index of a MenuItem in a MenuItemArray.
HookUpControlEvents(Object)

Overrides crosoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray.HookUpControlEvents*.

The ResetIndex method is not supported in the MenuItemArray class.
SetIndex(MenuItem,Int16)

Sets the index of the initial MenuItem in a MenuItemArray.
ShouldSerializeIndex(MenuItem)

Returns a value that indicates whether a MenuItem is a member of this MenuItemArray.

Events summary

Click

Occurs when a MenuItem in a MenuItemArray is clicked.
DrawItem

Occurs when a visual aspect of an owner-drawn MenuItem changes.
MeasureItem

Occurs each time an owner-drawn MenuItem needs to be drawn.
Popup

Occurs before a menu item's list of menu items is displayed.
Select

Occurs when the user rests the mouse pointer over a menu item.

Constructors

  • MenuItemArray()

    Initializes a new instance of the MenuItemArray class.

    public MenuItemArray ();

    Remarks

    When you instantiate a MenuItemArray, you must also call the SetIndex method to create the initial element in the array.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • MenuItemArray(IContainer)

    Initializes a new instance of the MenuItemArray class, specifying its container.

    public MenuItemArray (System.ComponentModel.IContainer Container);

    Parameters

    • Container
      IContainer

      The IContainer where the control array will be hosted.

    Remarks

    When you instantiate a MenuItemArray, you must also call the SetIndex method to create the initial element in the array.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Properties

  • Item(Int16)

    Gets a specific element of a MenuItemArray by index. Read-only.

    public System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem this[short Index] { get; }

    Parameters

    • Index
      Int16

      A Short that specifies the position of an element of the control array.

    Property Value

    • MenuItem

      A MenuItem at the specified Index in the control array.

    Remarks

    The Item property is the default property for a control array. Therefore, the following lines of code are equivalent. 

    MsgBox(CStr(MenuItemArray.Item(1).Text))  
MsgBox(CStr(MenuItemArray(1).Text))
    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Methods

  • CanExtend(Object)

    Gets a value that determines whether a control is a member of a MenuItemArray.

    public bool CanExtend (object target);

    Parameters

    • target
      Object

      A MenuItem control.

    Returns

    • Boolean

      true if target is a member of the control array; otherwise false.

    Remarks

    The CanExtend method can be used to determine whether a specific MenuItem control is the base element of the control array from which the other elements were cloned.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • GetControlInstanceType()

    Overrides crosoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray.GetControlInstanceType*.

    protected override Type GetControlInstanceType ();

    Returns

    • Type

      The MenuItemArray class is the base class for all control arrays that are used in applications upgraded from Visual Basic 6.0. Because this class is not typically used to create an instance of the class, this Protected method is usually not called directly but is instead called by a derived class.

    Remarks

    This method cannot be called from your application's code. Use the GetType method instead.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • GetIndex(MenuItem)

    Gets the index of a MenuItem in a MenuItemArray.

    public short GetIndex (System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem o);

    Parameters

    • o
      MenuItem

      A MenuItem in the control array.

    Returns

    • Int16

      A Short that represents the index of the specified MenuItem.

    Remarks

    This method can be used to retrieve the index for the specified MenuItem.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • HookUpControlEvents(Object)

    Overrides crosoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6.BaseControlArray.HookUpControlEvents*.

    protected override void HookUpControlEvents (object o);

    Parameters

    • o
      Object

      An Object.

    Remarks

    This method cannot be called from your application's code. Use AddHandler to hook up events for any controls that are added by using the Load method.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • ResetIndex(MenuItem)

    The ResetIndex method is not supported in the MenuItemArray class.

    public void ResetIndex (System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem o);

    Parameters

    • o
      MenuItem

      A Control.

    Remarks

    This method is not supported, and calling it does not raise an exception.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • SetIndex(MenuItem,Int16)

    Sets the index of the initial MenuItem in a MenuItemArray.

    public void SetIndex (System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem o, short Index);

    Parameters

    • o
      MenuItem

      A MenuItem in the control array.

    • Index
      Int16

      A Short that represents the index of the specified MenuItem.

    Remarks

    The SetIndex method should only be called when you are creating the initial element in the control array. To add subsequent elements, call the Load method and specify the Index.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • ShouldSerializeIndex(MenuItem)

    Returns a value that indicates whether a MenuItem is a member of this MenuItemArray.

    public bool ShouldSerializeIndex (System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem o);

    Parameters

    • o
      MenuItem

      A MenuItem in the control array.

    Returns

    • Boolean

      true if o is a member of this control array; otherwise, false.

    Remarks

    If the specified MenuItem is a member of a different MenuItemArray, ShouldSerializeIndex returns false.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

Events

  • Click

    Occurs when a MenuItem in a MenuItemArray is clicked.

    public event EventHandler Click;

    Remarks

    The Click event passes an EventArgs to its event handler. Therefore it only indicates that a click has occurred. If you need more specific mouse information (button, number of clicks, wheel rotation, or location), use the MouseClick event. However, the MouseClick event will not be raised if the click is caused by action other than that of the mouse, such as pressing the ENTER key.

    A double-click is determined by the mouse settings of the user's operating system. The user can set the time between clicks of a mouse button that should be considered a double-click instead of two clicks. The Click event is raised every time that a control is double-clicked. For example, if you have event handlers for the Click and DoubleClick events of a control, the Click and DoubleClick events are raised when the control is double-clicked and both methods are called. If a control is double-clicked and that control does not support the DoubleClick event, the Click event might be raised two times.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • DrawItem

    Occurs when a visual aspect of an owner-drawn MenuItem changes.

    public event System.Windows.Forms.DrawItemEventHandler DrawItem;

    Remarks

    This event is used by an owner-drawn MenuItem.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • MeasureItem

    Occurs each time an owner-drawn MenuItem needs to be drawn.

    public event System.Windows.Forms.MeasureItemEventHandler MeasureItem;

    Remarks

    You can create an event handler for this event to specify the size an item is made before it is drawn in the DrawItem event.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • Popup

    Occurs before a menu item's list of menu items is displayed.

    public event EventHandler Popup;

    Remarks

    This event occurs only when a menu item has submenu items to display. You can use this event handler to add, remove, enable, disable, check, or uncheck menu items based on the state of your application before they are displayed.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.

  • Select

    Occurs when the user rests the mouse pointer over a menu item.

    public event EventHandler Select;

    Remarks

    This event is typically raised when the user rests the mouse pointer over the menu item. The event can also be raised when the user highlights a menu item by using the keyboard to scroll to the menu item with the arrow keys. You can use this event to display a detailed Help string pertaining to this menu item in an application's status bar.

    For more information about how to handle events, see NIB: Consuming Events.

    Note

    Functions and objects in the Microsoft.VisualBasic.Compatibility.VB6 namespace are provided for use by the tools for upgrading from Visual Basic 6.0 to Visual Basic. In most cases, these functions and objects duplicate functionality that you can find in other namespaces in the .NET Framework. They are necessary only when the Visual Basic 6.0 code model differs significantly from the .NET Framework implementation.
